utterances: I saw she was such an accomplished writer.
We just both thought if she could even strum a few chords on the guitar, she'd just be away.
But in these first few chords - I think I showed her E Minor and A Major.
And between those two chords, she managed to write some fantastic songs.
In 2016, those songs landed on an EP.

(Singing) Like we hurtin' for stealin' (ph), had you paying for something you don't need.
They pose as the deliverer, the image of your dream, but the bailiff's always in your range.
Run away, run away, run away, fly away.
Fly away, fly away, fly away, bird.
It was a first step for a new solo artist who'd taken on a new name - Yola Carter.
The buzz about Carter's music reached the Americana scene in the U.S.
In-demand producer Dan Auerbach of The Black Keys brought her into his Nashville studio to write and record her debut album with all the bells and whistles.
We have this kind of funky track here.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
You know, it's kind of a - at the very basis of the tracks is the guitar and the vocal.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
We have a special process here with the guitars.
And we have a crew here of musicians that we use regularly.
Musicians who played on Elvis Presley, Roy Orbison and Aretha Franklin records that Carter revered.
(Soundbite of applause)
Well, you know, I think when you talk about what makes us feel good about ourselves, that is a very individual concern.
What might make me feel good might not make you feel good and vice versa.
But I don't know that the purpose of television is to make people feel good about themselves.
Television is a business; clearly the protesters don't understand that.
Television is in the business of making money and the decisions that they make are influenced by what they consider to be the bottom line.
Television is not there, you know, for social reasons, for cultural reasons, even though it does, you know, bleed over into those areas.
At the end of the day, it's a profit-making venture.
And people need to keep this in mind.
But the point is, you know, it's not - there's a lot of channels on television now, you know?
If you can't find something to watch, which, you know, sometimes is difficult, that's a personal issue.
It's not a public issue.
Well, Todd Boyd, thank you so much.
Thank you.
We've been speaking with Todd Boyd, professor of critical studies at the University of Southern California's School of Cinematic Arts.
This is SCIENCE FRIDAY from NPR.
I'm Ira Flatow.
Got any plans to head out to the beach this summer?
How about Cape Cod?
In a couple of years, you could see, you could be seeing dozens of wind turbines in Nantucket Sound turning out green power for the Cape and islands.
The Cape Wind Farm just got the final green light from the U.S.
government for construction to begin on the country's first offshore wind farm, 130 turbines that will stretch out, oh, up about 40 stories into the sky.
My next guest says that from the beach, they won't look any bigger than a half-inch on the horizon.
Joining me now to talk about the project is the CEO of Cape Wind Associates, Jim Gordon.
He's here with us in our studios in New York.
And if you'd like to ask questions, please join us.
Our number is 1-800-989-8255.
You can also tweet us, @scifri, @-S-C-I-F-R-I.
Welcome back, Jim.
Hi, Ira, how are you?
Only 10 years, huh?
Only 10 years.

The exciting thing is that a new, inexhaustible, clean resource is about to be harnessed for greater energy independence, new green jobs, more stable electric costs and hopefully catching up with the Europeans and Asians, who are putting offshore wind farms off their coasts.
So there are no more obstacles in your way?
Well, we are completely permitted now.
We do have some legal challenges that the opponents have put forth.
But, you know, Ira, we've been at this for 10 years, and we have met our opponents in courts or in regulatory arenas for that time, and our record has been 15 and 0.
So we do think that the legal challenges are a nuisance and designed to delay and obstruct the process.

But we believe that this project will get into construction by the end of the year, and we will be generating clean electricity for the Cape and islands and hopefully inspiring other Atlantic coastal states to look at tapping their offshore wind resources, also.
Can you make it cheap enough to be competitive?
Well, let's put it this way, Ira: Offshore wind is a bargain when you consider the external costs of burning fossil fuels and generating electricity with nuclear power.
As you know, mining and extracting coal and oil and natural gas, they take a toll on the environment, our health and military expenditures in order to protect Persian Gulf supply lines.
So when you look at the costs that we avoid by using offshore wind and other renewable energy resources, definitely it's competitive.
And in the cost per cents per kilowatt hour to the consumer, is that price competitive enough?
Right now, the cost of offshore wind, if you look just at the -comparing it with the kilowatt price on your electric bill, is higher.
But the point is we already see oil prices and natural gas prices and electricity prices rising.
The advantage of using offshore wind is you have a more stable electric costs that are not subject to the volatility of fossil fuel prices.
And so give us a timeline when we might see the first of these wind turbines actually be erected.
Be erected?
We're hopeful that in 2014, 2013, 2014, we'll start seeing these majestic offshore wind turbines creating a better energy future for the people on the Cape and islands.
And just to go over the numbers again, I'm talking 130?

130 wind turbines that will produce, on average, over 75 percent of the Cape and islands electricity with zero pollutant emissions and greenhouse gas emissions, zero water consumption and zero waste discharge.
There is news about trying to build an underwater electrical backbone up the East Coast I'm sure you're familiar with.
That's correct.
Would that stretch up into Nantucket with your wind turbines?
Right now, the plans for that undersea transmission line goes from Virginia to New Jersey.
So Cape Wind would be building its own transmission line that would hook in to the existing grid and provide this clean, renewable resource to the people in Massachusetts.
And you can sell everything that you can make, all the electricity.

Absolutely not.
I did it from an honest and a spiritual viewpoint and I want people to get the exact feeling that I had when I was choosing this music.
And if we stop trying to pigeonhole gospel music, then gospel music will go a lot farther and it will be advanced farther than it is today.
All right now, Ann, I know you've been talking about this over the last few months and you talk about being a grandmamma.
You have to be two things.
You have to be crazy proud right now with all of what America has seen with your granddaughter, Paris, up there on American Idol.
And I would suspect every week it must be terribly nerve wracking, too, for you.
Absolutely both, absolutely.
I'm overwhelmed, I'm excited.
Sometimes I'm upset, sometimes I'm nervous.
So you have all those things wrapped up into one, but I am definitely, most definitely proud.
To have your granddaughter to call you and say, Granny, I'm doing this song.

What do you think about this and to stand there -- and to stand there and sing with the contestants who are much older than her -- in their 20s and then she being 17 -- not having any fear but just going out there and doing her best, it does me more than proud.
And let me take you back to a question that I know a lot of people have asked you really since the first solo album.

The success that you achieved and it brought notoriety to you with Sounds of Blackness, will this be one of those things that you'll be able to run back and forth the rest of your career between the solo projects and occasionally going back with them?
Would you like to be able to continue doing that kind of thing?
Well, there's always a statement that came from Mr. Gary Hines, who's the director of the Sounds of Blackness, that once a Sounds, always a Sounds member.
Sounds of Blackness was an extended family for me and I know that I will always have the same love for them and always be able to go back.
